Telegram's ad policy prohibits political ads. It is unclear if and how ad submissions are screened. (Political Advertising – policy & tools)

WhatsApp uses "automated tools, manual review, and user reports, to detect abuse." Users are encouraged to report posts that violate guidelines. Nothing in the guidelines addresses misinformation or e

Discourse allows users to flag posts. Flagged posts are reviewed by volunteer forum moderators to ensure compliance with the group's "terms of service, FAQ, and other published rules/guidelines." (Eve
Facebook allows Trump's calls for a Muslim ban to stand, despite violating the platform's Hate Speech policy. (Event/Application of Policy)
Facebook rolls out third party fact checking program. (Misinformation – policy & tools)
Facebook rolls out third party fact checking program. (Misinformation – policy & tools)
Introduction of authorization process confirming the identify and location of entities running ads. (Political Advertising – policy & tools)
Ad Archive replaced by Ad Library. (Political Advertising – policy & tools)
Launch of Ad Archive in the U.S. (initially rolled out in Canada). (Political Advertising – policy & tools)
Facebook/Instagram label ads to indicate the entity that paid for the ad. (Political Advertising – policy & tools)
Facebook announces expanded policies to protect against voter suppression. (Election Interference – policy & tools)
Launch of Facebook Protect, greater security to protect the accounts of political candidates from hacks. (Election Interference – policy & tools)
U.S. users are provided with an option to turn off political ads. (Political Advertising – policy & tools)
Voting Information Center launches. (Voting – policy & tools)
Facebook announces it will label state controlled media in Page and Ad Library . (Political Advertising – policy & tools)
Facebook labels all posts about voting to point users to credible/official resources, such as usa.gov/voting. (Voting – policy & tools)
Facebook amends policy to prohibit posts that "use militarized language or suggest that the goal is to intimidate, exert control, or display power over election officials or voters." (Voting – policy
President Trump is banned from Facebook and Instagram. (Event/Application of Policy)
Meta dissolves its Responsible Innovation Team. (Staffing)
Meta announces the merger of its Business Integrity Unit, the team that moderates ad content, with its Central Integrity Team, which moderates user posts. (Staffing)

In lead up to 2022 election, The Washington Post conducts an analysis of candidate posts claiming rigged/fraudulent elections and finds that virtually none are labeled on Facebook or Twitter. (Misinfo
Change in Meta's political advertising policies shifts to allow assertions that the 2020 election was stolen. (Political Advertising – policy & tools)
Meta lays off leadership and staff of the Meta Journalism Project. Although the Project still appears on Facebook's website, the last listed milestone is from March 2022. (Staffing)
It is reported that Meta has ended contracts of 200 contact moderators and laid off 100+ people in the trust & safety and integrity space. (Staffing)
Former President Trump is readmitted to Meta platforms after having been banned for two years. (Event/Application of Policy)
Meta staff cuts amount to a quarter of its workforce. (Staffing)
Senate Committee on Rules and Administration publishes letter stating that Meta retains only 20% of staff who previously worked on election-related issues. (Staffing)
Senate Committee on Rules and Administration publishes letter stating that Meta retains only 20% of staff who previously worked on election-related issues. (Staffing)
First 4 of 16 papers released assessing "the impact of Facebook and Instagram on key political attitudes and behaviors during the US 2020 election cycle." (Event/Application of Policy)

The Washington Post reports that "Meta has quietly begun offering users new controls to opt out of the fact-checking program, allowing debunked posts ... to spread in participants’ news-feeds with a w
Reorg of relevant community standards. Voter/Census Interference rolled into 'Misrepresentation' Category, Voter/Census Fraud still present under 'Coordinating Harm.' (Voting – policy & tools)
Meta bars political advertisements from using the Meta Generative AI ads creation tools in Ads Manager. (Political Advertising – policy & tools)
Meta releases their public facing plan for the 2024 elections, stressing continuity in their approach with previous elections. (Misinformation – policy & tools)
Meta announces that it will again block new political ads the last week before the 2024 election. (Political Advertising – policy & tools)

As a part of their plan for the 2024 election, Meta announces that "advertisers will also have to disclose when they use AI or other digital techniques to create or alter a political or social issue a

fields.summary: Anticipating possible election disputes, Twitter announces policy to handle early claims of victory.
fields.details: "To determine the results of an election in the US, we require either an announcement from state election officials, or a public projection from at least two authoritative, national news outlets that make independent election calls. Tweets which include premature claims will be labeled and direct people to our official US election page."

fields.summary: U.S. users are provided with an option to turn off political ads.
Elon Musk acquires Twitter.
Musk announces a "general amnesty to suspended accounts" after conducting a poll of users on the topic.
fields.details: "The mass return of users who had been banned for such offenses as violent threats, harassment and misinformation."

fields.summary: Following Google's lead, Facebook announces they will not run political ads for 1 week after the election.
Identity verification expanded to all advertisers on YouTube (not just political).
fields.details: "Advertisers will need to submit personal identification, business incorporation documents or other information that proves who they are and the country in which they operate."

fields.summary: Launch of Twitter's Ads Transparency Center.
fields.details: "You should be able to search for any Twitter handle and bring up all the ad campaigns from that account that have run for the past seven days. For political advertisers in the U.S., there will be additional data, including information around billing, ad spend, impressions per tweet and demographic targeting."

fields.summary: TikTok responds to stolen election conspiracies by applying its existing 'banned hashtags' policy to linked hashtags. Enforcement was reportedly spotty.

Gab employs a hands off approach to content moderation: "Gab believes gabbers are responsible adults providing mute or block options to manage your own feed." Users can report "direct threats, porn, doxxing, fedposting, site abuse, spam, and illegal posts"
fields.details: Each Gab channel is moderated by volunteer admins and has its own posting guidelines. Gab asserts that it will take down illegal content (and cooperate with authorities), but otherwise brands itself as free speech platform.

fields.summary: Google announces that all election advertisers must include a disclosure when their ads contain AI generated content (across all Google platforms).
Thread launches.
Changes to recommendation system concerning "borderline" content in regards to its compliance with community standards.
fields.details: "And since January 2019, we’ve launched over 30 different changes to reduce recommendations of borderline content and harmful misinformation. The result is a 70% average drop in watch time of this content coming from non-subscribed recommendations in the U.S."

fields.summary: X cuts half its Election Integrity team, including leadership.
fields.details: When asked of the cuts, Musk responded, "Oh you mean the 'Election Integrity' Team that was undermining election integrity? Yeah, they’re gone."

fields.summary: Musk announces "Twitter will be forming a content moderation council with widely diverse viewpoints." No further action to establish said council has been taken since this announcement.

European Commission Vice President Věra Jourová, in charge of EU digital affairs and democracy states: “X, former Twitter — who is not under the Code anymore — is the platform with the largest ratio of mis- or disinformation posts."
fields.details: The remarks occur in the context of a report from the Code of Practice on Disinformation. Twitter had previously been party to the Code but dropped out under Musk.

fields.summary: Google announces that all election advertisers must include a disclosure when their ads contain AI generated content (across all Google platforms).
fields.details: "A mid-November policy update to require that election-related ads must include a disclosure if they contain "synthetic content that inauthentically depicts real or realistic-looking people or events."

fields.summary: TikTok announces that while paid ads will be allowed, political ads will not be.
fields.details: "Any paid ads that come into the community need to fit the standards for our platform, and the nature of paid political ads is not something we believe fits the TikTok platform experience. To that end, we will not allow paid ads that promote or oppose a candidate, current leader, political party or group, or issue at the federal, state, or local level – including election-related ads, advocacy ads, or issue ads."

fields.summary: YouTube launches educational media literacy campaign.
fields.details: "providing tips on identifying different manipulation tactics used to spread misinformation – from using emotional language to cherry picking information. This campaign will first launch in the U.S., and we’ll expand to other countries over time."

fields.summary: Twitter's new Head of Trust & Safety says "Elon Musk's Twitter is leaning heavily on automation to moderate content, doing away with certain manual reviews and favoring restrictions on distribution rather than removing certain speech outright."
Twitter Blue (verification) scheme rolls out for the second time, with supposed safety checks to prevent impersonation.
fields.details: Labels are also replaced by checkmarks - grey for government accounts and blue for 'some' businesses.

fields.summary: Trust and Safety lead Yoel Roth resigns.
fields.details: In an op-ed a week later, Yoel states: "a Twitter whose policies are defined by edict has little need for a trust and safety function dedicated to its principled development ... to truly understand the shape of Twitter going forward, I’d encourage looking not just at the choices the company makes but also at how Mr. Musk makes them."

fields.summary: WSJ reports that Threads is not labeling state-run accounts, which is standard practice on Instagram and Facebook.
fields.details: "Meta launched Threads before the service was fully built out to capitalize on Twitter’s struggles under Musk, The Wall Street Journal has reported. That means Threads lacks basic moderation features including the labels."

fields.summary: In lead up to 2022 election, The Washington Post conducts analysis of candidate posts claiming rigged/fraudulent elections and finds that virtually none are labeled by Facebook or Twitter.
Ban on paid ads that suggest voting is useless or advise people not to vote.
fields.details: Came out of recommendation from civil rights audit.

fields.summary: Twitter fires top officials -- including head of legal policy, trust, and safety Vijaya Gadde, who was behind the decision to suspend President Trump's account.
fields.details: Musk had repeated criticism of Gadde as Twitter's "chief censor."

fields.summary: A letter from the Senate Committee on Rules and Administration observes that 80% of staff working election issues had been laid off.
fields.details: A letter from the Senate Committee on Rules and Administration states "this month one report stated that Meta has only 20 percent of the number of staff who worked on election-related issues in 2020 - or 60 employees down from 300 - and that additional layoffs are planned."

fields.summary: Meta staff cuts amount to a quarter of its workforce.
fields.details:
The Washington Post reports that "at least a half-dozen current and former Meta employees who have worked on trust and safety issues say severe cuts in those divisions could hamper the company’s ability to respond to viral political misinformation, foreign influence campaigns and regulatory challenges."

"Meta follows after announcing cuts that amount to almost a quarter of its workforce, which was around 87,000 staff in 2022. CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced cuts of 11,000 jobs in November, then a further cut of 10,000 in March."

fields.summary: Twitter Rules bans content in the following categories: 1) misinformation on how to participate in civil process 2) suppression and intimidation 3) false or misleading affiliation.
fields.details: Tweets that violate policies have "reduced visibility" (de-amplified) and labels, but are not removed.

fields.summary: Voting Information Center launches.
fields.details: The Voting Information Center provides "authoritative information" concerning voter eligiblity, process to request absentee ballots, in person voting, deadlines. Its goal is to register 4 million votes (claimed up from 2 million in 2016 and 2018). All users 18+ see a link at the top of their page instructing them to register to vote.

fields.summary: Content moderation continues to take place under the "misleading information" banner.
fields.details: "We continue to enforce our rules against intentionally misleading election-related content ... We have also taken action on Tweets sharing media regarding elections and political issues with misleading or incorrect party affiliation information."

fields.summary: X rolls out Community Notes (its crowdsourced moderation tool) to images. This occurs amidst rising concerns about deepfake images.
Following the decision to allow political ads, Twitter announces 1) a certification process for ad sponsors and 2) a disclosure process related to political ads.
fields.details:
Twitter has not provided details about how the certification process requires. The form to be certified is not publically available.

To get details about all political campaigning ads running on our platform, users can request a disclosure report online. This appears to place the burden on the public, rather than proactive disclosure by Twitter

fields.summary: Facebook announces it will label state controlled media in Page and Ad Library .
fields.details: "We’re providing greater transparency into these publishers because they combine the influence of a media organization with the strategic backing of a state, and we believe people should know if the news they read is coming from a publication that may be under the influence of a government."

fields.summary: WhatsApp uses "automated tools, manual review, and user reports, to detect abuse." Users are encouraged to report posts that violate guidelines. Nothing in the guidelines addresses misinformation or elections specifically.
fields.details:
Per ProPublica, WhatsApp uses contract workers to review content flagged by users for possible guideline violations.

Guidelines instruct users to abide by the below terms. Nothing pertains to elections or disinformation, although calls for election violence would run afoul on the basis of inciting violence:

  • "Do not share illegal content or engage in illegal activity of any kind," including child sexual abuse/endangerment, support for terrorist, hate or criminal organization, and violation of intellectual property.
  • "Do not share content that could cause serious harm to people," including credible threats, "incitement of violence, organization or coordination of violent or criminal activities, or content that encourages suicide or self-injury." Disallowed content includes "human trafficking [or promotion of] sexual violence, sexual assault, or sexual exploitation."
  • "Do not engage in fraud"
  • "Keep content age-appropriate for WhatsApp’s user base," avoiding overly violent or graphic images, pornography, or facilitating commercial sexual services.

fields.summary: Washington Post reporting on Facebook's previous consideration of a ban on political advertising.
fields.details: According to Washington Post reporting, Facebook considered and planned to implement a ban on political advertising. Efforts began in summer 2021, but were shelved by summer 2022 in light of Musk's plans to turn Twitter into a free speech haven.

fields.summary: YouTube changes policy to allow for content concerning the Big Steal.
fields.details: "We will stop removing content that advances false claims that widespread fraud, errors, or glitches occurred in the 2020 and other past US Presidential elections. This goes into effect today, Friday, June 2."

fields.summary: Removal of all state media labels.
fields.details: Twitter placed state media labels on BBC, NPR and other media outlets that receive public funding. A backlash resulted; Twitter used this as an opportunity to remove ALL labels designating government control/funding "allowing propaganda from China, Russia and other countries to be more widely seen and believed." The move coincided with a leak of DOD internal documents noting Russian success in evading detection on social media platforms and spreading misinformation

fields.summary: Twitter announces they will remove tweets that encourage violence or call for people to interfere with election results or the smooth operation of polling place.
Twitter launches 2020 Election Hub at top of Explore tab.
fields.details: The Hub includes: English and Spanish language election news "in the form of Twitter Moments created by reputable news outlets themselves"; debate and other election event livestreams; voter educations PSAs.

fields.summary: TikTok updates community guidelines to more explicitly "prohibit synthetic or manipulated content that misleads users by distorting the truth of events in a way that could cause harm."
fields.details: "Our intent is to protect users from things like shallow or deep fakes, so while this kind of content was broadly covered by our guidelines already, this update makes the policy clearer for our users. "

fields.summary: Musical.ly (US based video app) and TikTok merge, leading to TikTok becoming available in the U.S.
Twitter limits circulation of unverified NY Post story concerning Hunter Biden in accordance with its policy on Hacked Materials.
Telegram utilizes a minimalist approach to content moderation. Users can report content for review and Telegram states that it will take down illegal content.
fields.details:
Telegram's terms of service state that users agree not to: "Use our service to send spam or scam users; Promote violence on publicly viewable Telegram channels, bots, etc.; Post illegal pornographic content on publicly viewable Telegram channels, bots, etc." Their FAQs state that they take down illegal content (when it is flagged).

Users can report content which falls into the following categories: child abuse, copyright violations, fake account, illegal drugs, personal details, pronography, violence and spam. However, the platform does not take an active approach to content moderation.

fields.summary: Newly designed misleading information labels for 2022 elections announced.
fields.details: "The new labels increased click through rates by 17%, meaning more people were clicking labels to read debunking content. We also saw notable decreases in engagement with Tweets labeled with the new design: -13% in replies, -10% in Retweets and -15% in likes."

fields.summary: Facebook allows Trump's calls for a Muslim ban to stand, despite violating the platform's Hate Speech policy.
Elon Musk acquires Twitter.

Parler returns online, hosted by SkySilk Cloud Services. The platform states they will employ basic content moderation in the form of a 'trolling filter,' but that the flagged posts will remain on the platform for users to optionally view.
fields.details: "Parler says there will be a "trolling filter" in which content that attacks someone based on race, sex, sexual orientation or religion will be covered up. Yet those who want to view the content will be allowed by clicking through the filter."

fields.summary: Parler is dropped by the Google Play Store, Apple App Store, and Amazon Web Services in the aftermath of January 6 owing to its failure to police violent content and representing a risk to public safety. With no hosting platform, Parler goes offline.
Facebook announces a prohibition on new ads during last week of campaign.
A former Twitter employee turned whistleblower calls into question Twitter's capacities to enforce its election policies.
Twitter disbands its external advisory Trust and Safety Council.
Facebook creates new policy section on Inauthentic Behavior - previously housed under Misrepresentation.
fields.details:
Inauthentic Behavior is defined as "the actors behind these campaigns are using deceptive behaviors to conceal the identity of the organization behind a campaign, make the organization or its activity appear more popular or trustworthy than it is, or evade our enforcement efforts"

The content prohibition includes foreign government interference: "We do not allow entities to engage in, or claim to engage in foreign or government interference, which is Coordinated Inauthentic Behavior conducted on behalf of a foreign or government actor."

fields.summary: YouTube adds a 'how to vote' feature. Also adds "timely reminders across YouTube and our social handles on how to register, how to vote and where to vote" in weeks leading up to U.S. election.
fields.details: "This tool provides authoritative information about how you can vote in your state—such as ID requirements, registration and voting deadlines, and guidance for different means of voting, like in person or mail. Google works with non-partisan, third-party data partners, such as Democracy Works, who aggregate official data directly from state and county election administrators, and link to your state government’s official website for more information."

fields.summary: YouTube increases the penalty for violating election misinformation policy
fields.details: "YouTube announced that any channels that violated its election misinformation policy would receive a “strike,” and that channels that received three strikes in a 90-day period would be permanently removed."

fields.summary: It is reported that Meta has ended contracts of 200 contact moderators and laid off 100+ people in the trust & safety and integrity space.
fields.details: "Meta reportedly ended the contracts of about 200 content moderators in early January. It also laid off at least 16 members of Instagram’s well-being group and more than 100 positions related to trust, integrity and responsibility, according to documents filed with the U.S. Department of Labor." Staffing cuts kills a new fact checking tool 6 months in the making ("would let third-party fact-checkers like The Associated Press and Reuters, as well as credible experts, add comments at the top of questionable articles on Facebook as a way to verify their trustworthiness.")

fields.summary: YouTube announces ad verification procedures and starts labeling ads to indicate the paying entity.
Facebook announces expanded policies to protect against voter suppression.
fields.details: Previously "prohibit offers to buy or sell votes as well as misrepresentations about the dates, locations, times and qualifications for casting a ballot." Newly added: "banning misrepresentations about how to vote, such as claims that you can vote using an online app, and statements about whether a vote will be counted ... "

fields.summary: Twitter head of trust and safety Ella Irwin resigns.
fields.details: Irwin had held the role for 7 months, since the resignation of her predecessor.

fields.summary: YouTube rolls out YouChoose 2020 + voter education PSAs (via information panels).
fields.details: "an interactive voting special that takes you through the key steps in the voting process using the YouTube meme of your choosing — from a cooking tutorial that compares voting to following a recipe, to an auto repair video that breaks down the ‘nuts and bolts’ of voting"

fields.summary: Twitter begins prebunking "false information about voting by mail and election results" by placing information at the top of users feeds.
Limited application of 'Sensitive Events' policy concerning January 6 puts a freeze on ads. The move is intended to slow the spread of misinformation.
fields.details: While this policy is in place, advertisers are not able to run ads referencing candidates, the election, its outcome, the presidential inauguration, the presidential impeachment process, violence at the U.S. Capitol, or future planned protests on these topics.

fields.summary: Although Threads is to follow Instagram's community guidelines, Meta states that Threads will be exempt from Meta's regular fact checking programs. Media Matters finds that Threads does not appear to be enforcing Meta's policies against hate speech.
fields.details: "The company will not extend its existing fact-checking program to Threads, spokesperson Christine Pai said in an emailed statement on Thursday. This eliminates a distinguishing feature of how Meta has managed misinformation on its other apps."

fields.summary: Facebook/Instagram label ads to indicate the entity that paid for the ad.
fields.details: Political ads are labeled in a way that indicates who paid for the ad (“Paid for by” disclosure). Further details on the reach and audience also made available.

fields.summary: YouTube expands election ad transparency efforts to include state level elections.
fields.details: "expanding the coverage of our election advertising transparency to include U.S. state-level candidates and officeholders, ballot measures, and ads that mention federal or state political parties, so that all of those ads will now be searchable and viewable as well."

fields.summary: Twitter lifts the ban on former President Trump's account.
fields.details: "When asked about what measures are being taken to combat misinformation ahead of the 2024 elections, why Trump was allowed to return to the platform and whether it has comment on data that shows misinformation on its platform has risen under Musk’s leadership, Twitter replied with a poop emoji."

fields.summary: Ad Library is modified to include information about targeting choices and ad delivery.

Google's plan for the 2024 elections emphasizes AI as an enforcement tool and as a threat in spreading misinformation. Minimal additions to platform election protections outside the requirement for synesthetic media labeling and disclosure.
fields.details:
• Reiterates existing requirement that election advertisers must "prominently disclose when their ads include realistic synthetic content."
  • Introduces requirement for "creators to disclose when they’ve created realistic altered or synthetic content." Election related synthetic will also be labeled.
  • Notes that plan to "restrict the types of election-related queries for which Bard and [Search Generative Experience] SGE will return responses."

Beyond the AI space, Google continues previous voter education efforts and maintains its identity verification process for advertisers. The YouTube annoucement reiterates disallowed content concerning elections, with no changes, and notes the preferencing of information labels at the top of search results.

fields.summary: YouTube strengthens "Elections misinformation policies." Content claiming the election was stolen will be removed, but only if posted after Dec 9 2020.
fields.details:
"YouTube said it would remove videos that promoted the unfounded theory that widespread errors and fraud changed the outcome of the presidential election."

"Yesterday was the safe harbor deadline for the U.S. Presidential election and enough states have certified their election results to determine a President-elect. Given that, we will start removing any piece of content uploaded today (or anytime after) that misleads people by alleging that widespread fraud or errors changed the outcome of the 2020 U.S. Presidential election"

fields.summary: Meta announces that it will again block new political ads the last week before the 2024 election.
TikTok adds an in app reporting feature for election misinformation.
fields.details: "Election misinformation option to our in-app reporting feature so that people can easily report content or accounts for review."

fields.summary: Launch of Political Campaigning Policy, establishing verification requirements for political advertisers.
fields.details: Verification requirements: "Advertisers who want to run political campaigning ads for Federal elections to self-identify and certify that they are located in the US Candidates and committees will have to provide their FEC ID, and non-FEC registered organizations and individuals will have to submit a notarized form."

fields.summary: TikTok released its policy on synthetic media. Depending on the likelihood of resulting harm, the content may be labeled or removed..
fields.details: "You may not deceptively share synthetic or manipulated media that are likely to cause harm. In addition, we may label Tweets containing synthetic and manipulated media to help people understand the media’s authenticity and to provide additional context."

fields.summary: YouTube imposes limits on election ad targeting.
fields.details: Under the new policy "election ads [are limited in] audience targeting to the following general categories: age, gender, and general location (postal code level)."

fields.summary: Framed under the Civic Integrity Policy, Twitter adds limitations on tweets with misleading label. The stated intent of this design feature is to reduce the visibility of misinformation.
fields.details: "People must tap through a warning to see these Tweets, and then will only be able to Quote Tweet; likes, Retweets and replies will be turned off, and these Tweets won’t be algorithmically recommended by Twitter." This feature only targets accounts with significant reach, limited to "US political figures (including candidates and campaign accounts), US-based accounts with more than 100,000 followers."

fields.summary: Discourse allows users to flag posts. Flagged posts are reviewed by volunteer forum moderators to ensure compliance with the group's "terms of service, FAQ, and other published rules/guidelines."
fields.details: The Discourse FAQ lack hard and fast rules about what is not permitted on the site. It instructs users not to "post anything obscene or sexually explicit ... harass or grief anyone, impersonate people, or expose their private information[,] ... post spam or otherwise vandalize the forum" or to post violations of intellectual property. Misinformation and/or election content is not addressed; flagged posts are subject to the discretion of forum moderators.

fields.summary: Enhanced account security for  government officials, candidates for office, journalists.
Google rolls out image-customizing generative AI ads tools, which includes a list of "political keywords" blocked from being used as prompts.
Expansion on labeling political accounts to include state media accounts.
fields.details: Applies to "key government officials, including foreign ministers, institutional entities, ambassadors, official spokespeople, and key diplomatic leaders. At this time, our focus is on senior officials and entities who are the official voice of the state abroad ... We will also no longer amplify state-affiliated media accounts or their Tweets through our recommendation systems."

fields.summary: YouTube clarifies restrictions on election ad content, including a prohibition on manipulated media and false claims.
fields.details: "we’re clarifying our ads policies and adding examples to show how our policies prohibit things like “deep fakes” (doctored and manipulated media), misleading claims about the census process, and ads or destinations making demonstrably false claims that could significantly undermine participation or trust in an electoral or democratic process. "

fields.summary: Twitter announces shift in enforcement philosophy - rather than removing content that violates terms, they will move towards de-amplifying the content.
fields.details: "Our approach to policy enforcement will rely more heavily on de-amplification of violative content: freedom of speech, but not freedom of reach."

fields.summary: Former President Trump is readmitted to Meta platforms after having been banned for two years.
Candidate account labels for 2022 elections announced with the aim of preventing fake accounts.
Change in Meta's political advertising policies shifts to allow assertions that the 2020 election was stolen.
fields.details: Meta prohibits ads that "call into question the legitimacy of an upcoming or ongoing election” in the U.S., Brazil, Israel and Italy, but permits ads that call into question the results of PAST elections -- to include 2020. Media reporting suggests that the change was made quietly after the 2022 midterms, with no publicity calling attention to the change. Media subsequently reported the change a year later, noting posts that had been made since the change that refer to the 2020 election as "stolen" and "rigged."

fields.summary: Revision of Civic Integrity Policy to include "label or remove false or misleading information intended to undermine public confidence in an election or other civic process."
fields.details: Tweets that violate policies have "reduced visibility" (de-amplified) and labeled, but are not removed.

fields.summary: In app election guide launches.
fields.details: "The elections guide offers information about candidates at the federal, state, and local level, powered by BallotReady; how to vote in every state, powered by the National Association of Secretaries of State; and educational videos about misinformation, media literacy, the elections process, and more, powered by MediaWise ... Our elections guide is built with user privacy in mind, so a user must visit the website for a state or a non-profit for anything that involves sharing their information, including registering to vote."

fields.summary: Business Insider reports that Twitter has fired 80% of its staff.
fields.details: In 2022, Twitter had 7800 employees. Musk fired 6300.

fields.summary: Expansion of content provided in information panels on election candidates.
fields.details: "an information panel with additional information about that candidate—for example, party affiliation and district—above search results."

fields.summary: In 2016, Facebook/Instagram had no election specific policies. Following the election, Mark Zuckerberg denies that fake news on Facebook influenced the election
Information panels expanded to apply to topics identified as being prone to misinformation/conspiracy.
fields.details: When users view a video whose theme is on a list, they are shown an information panel to "link to third-party sources around a small number of well-established topics that are subject to misinformation, such as the moon landing or QAnon." "For example, when people watch videos that encourage viewers to skip the MMR vaccine, we show information panels to provide more basic scientific context, linking to third-party sources."

fields.summary: Facebook announces it will remove misleading synthetic media.
Washington Post reports that Twitter trust and safety teams "have shrunk to dozens from a staff of 120 before Musk’s takeover."
Update to Hacked Political Materials policy in the context of political ads.
fields.details: Policy amended to disallow "ads that directly facilitate or advertise access to hacked material related to political entities within scope of Google's elections ads policies." Discussion of hacked materials is permitted.

fields.summary: In a letter to Meta employees, Mark Zuckerberg states "we’re focusing on returning to a more optimal ratio of engineers to other roles. "
Ad Transparency Center discontinued. Achieved version still available.
fields.details: "With the official prohibition of both Political and Issue Ads on Twitter in November 2019 and the establishment of a mandatory Cause-Based Ad certification and review process, the ATC no longer provides its original intended value."

fields.summary: In 2020, YouTube's content regulation policy did not have a section devoted to Elections. Some guidelines are housed under Spam, deceptive practices & scams policies. 3 of the content categories pertain to elections.
fields.details:
• Voter Suppression: Content aiming to mislead voters about the time, place, means or eligibility requirements for voting.
  • Candidate Eligibility: Content that advances false claims related to the technical eligibility requirements for current political candidates and sitting elected government officials to serve in office. Eligibility requirements considered are based on applicable national law, and include age, citizenship, or vital status.
  • Incitement to interfere in democratic processes: Content encouraging others to interfere with democratic processes, such as obstructing or interrupting voting procedures.

Consequences: "If your content violates this policy, we’ll remove the content and send you an email to let you know. If this is your first time violating our Community Guidelines, you’ll get a warning with no penalty to your channel. If it’s not, we’ll issue a strike against your channel. If you get 3 strikes, your channel will be terminated."

fields.summary: Pre-bunks for 2022 elections announced.
fields.details: Pre-bunks function by offering "prompts directly on people’s timelines in the US and in Search when people type related terms, phrases, or hashtags" previously identified as associated with misinformation.

fields.summary: Framed under the Civic Integrity Policy, Twitter adds additional context in "For You" tab.
fields.details: "There will be a description Tweet or article that represents or summarizes why that term is trending."

fields.summary: Twitter announces ban on all political content ads (candidates and issue based).
fields.details: "This isn’t about free expression. This is about paying for reach. And paying to increase the reach of political speech has significant ramifications that today’s democratic infrastructure may not be prepared to handle."

fields.summary: Twitter Blue Verified rolls out ("the paid version of the check marks that have long been appended to accounts of major corporations, celebrities, journalists and other influential people.") Accounts impersonating public figures quickly appear.

Expanding on prior option to turn off political adds, U.S. users are able to "turn off all social issue, electoral or political ads from candidates, Super PACs or other organizations that have the “Paid for by” political disclaimer on them."
TikTok adds banners on election content.
fields.details: "Election-related videos that directed viewers to the elections guide for up-to-date information and results."

fields.summary: Anticipating a close election, Google announces it will cease running political ads on all platforms (including YouTube) after polls close on Election Day.
Launch of Facebook Protect, greater security to protect the accounts of political candidates from hacks.
Third party fact checking expands to include Facebook videos and photos.
Telegram's ad policy prohibits political ads. It is unclear if and how ad submissions are screened.
fields.details: The ad policy states: "Ads must not promote political campaigns, elections, political parties, candidates, political or religious movements. Ads that are related to ongoing sensitive events or sensitive topics can be suspended for the meantime."

fields.summary: Meta releases their public facing plan for the 2024 elections, stressing continuity in their approach with previous elections.
fields.details: The fact sheet plays up platform features that encourage voter registration and the Voter Information Center. They note that posts rated by third party fact checkers as 'false' are displayed less prominantly, but do not mention the previous decision that allows users to turn off fact checking. Concerning political ads, the fact sheet states "we do not allow an ad to run if it’s rated as False, Altered, Partly False, or Missing Context."

fields.summary: TikTok employs a standard policy to identify problematic hashtags, block results and redirect users to Community Guidelines. This approach is described as "reducing discoverability."
fields.details:
This policy went into effect for the 2020 and continued in future election cycles. 

"We moved to quickly redirect misleading hashtags to our Community Guidelines instead of showing results, such as #sharpiegate #stopthesteal #patriotparty. This approach has also helped us combat QAnon content, though we continually must update our safeguards as content and terminology evolves."

In reality, this tactic likely has limited impact. As the New York Times reported "users cannot search the #StopTheSteal hashtag, but #StopTheSteallll had accumulated nearly a million views until TikTok disabled the hashtag after being contacted by The New York Times."

fields.summary: Facebook labels all posts about voting to point users to credible/official resources, such as usa.gov/voting.
fields.details: Facebook begins labeling posts about voting from federal officials and candidates, including presidential candidates, in the U.S. Labels direct people to credible information about elections, and will appear on posts regardless of whether they contain misinformation. These changes follow an external report that half of Facebook's top posts mentioning voting contained false or misleading information.

fields.summary: Google announces it will lift its temporary ban on all political ads, imposed following January 6.

A June 2023 letter from the Senate Committee on Rules and Administration states that "in January [2023] YouTube reported layoffs that left just one person in charge of handling misinformation policy globally."
Launch of Top News and Breaking News features.
fields.details:
"Top News shelf prominently highlights videos from news sources in search results ... last year we saw consumption of content from authoritative news partners’ channels grow by 60%."

In the context of breaking news, video takes time to be produced. In these cases, "we've started providing short previews of text-based news articles in search results on YouTube, along with a reminder that breaking and developing news can rapidly change."

fields.summary: In the effort to reduce the spread of misinformation, Twitter announces a change in feed curation, removing tweets from accounts that the user does not follow.
fields.details:
The product design change "prevent[s] “liked by” and “followed by” recommendations from people you don’t follow from showing up in your timeline and won’t send notifications for Tweets."


NOTE: found to be ineffective and is abandoned Dec 2020 ("we found that pausing these recommendations prevented many people from discovering new conversations and accounts to follow. ")

fields.summary: Facebook amends policy to prohibit posts that "use militarized language or suggest that the goal is to intimidate, exert control, or display power over election officials or voters."
Twitter stops removing content about Big Steal, stating that the State Civil Integrity policy only applies when the election is ongoing.
Days before election, Twitters cuts 15% of trust and safety team. Cuts included Neema Singh Guliani, lead on democracy, national security and civil rights policy.
fields.details: "Other teams that also perform critical content moderation suffered heavier cuts, including the Product Trust team, which develops policies to prevent new features from harming people, and the Health team, which implements policies from Trust and Safety."

fields.summary: Launch of Ad Archive in the U.S. (initially rolled out in Canada).
fields.details:
"An archive of federal-election related ads so that we can show both current and historical federal-election related ads" This feature was a compromise, noting calls to remove political ads following manipulation concerns from 2016. 

TechCrunch reported that the archive also applies to ads "dealing with political issues such as “abortion, guns, immigration or foreign policy.”"

fields.summary: Meta lays off leadership and staff of the Meta Journalism Project. Although the Project still appears on Facebook's website, the last listed milestone is from March 2022.
fields.details: These layoffs appears to be part of a broader trend of Meta retreating from engagement with journalism: "But Meta seems to be withdrawing from this work by canceling its news-adjacent programs. In the last year, the company announced it would terminate Instant Articles and Bulletin, its newsletter service. It also stopped paying U.S. publishers for their stories, changed the name of its “News Feed” to “Feed” and announced its “Top Stories” section would be curated by algorithms rather than humans beginning next year. "

fields.summary: Launch of Political Advertising Transparency Report.
fields.details: Searchable database that shows source of ad, spending on campaigns, timeline, number of views; verification process for organizations running ads.

fields.summary: Twitter permanently suspends the accounts of several journalists, claiming that they were engaged in doxing behavior of Musk.
fields.details: "The accounts belonging to CNN’s Donie O’Sullivan, The New York Times’ Ryan Mac, The Washington Post’s Drew Harwell and other journalists who have covered Musk aggressively in recent weeks were all abruptly permanently suspended. The account of progressive independent journalist Aaron Rupar was also banned."

fields.summary: To support external research, Twitter releases a database containing tweets and account information of Russian and Iranian efforts suspected to have interfered in the 2016 elections.
Responding to concerns over foreign involvement in the 2016 election, Facebook rolls out its 'Inauthentic Behavior' efforts.
fields.details: This workstream takes down coordinated networks of inauthentic accounts (fake names, multiple accounts), Pages and Groups that seek to manipulate public debate. The majority of inauthentic accounts are spam or sales related. The posts are generally caught based on behavior of the user (spamming) rather than the content itself

fields.summary: Twitter begins labeling synthetic media
fields.details:
The three questions used to determine whether to apply a label are: 

  • Are the media synthetic or manipulated?
  • Are the media shared in a deceptive manner?
  • Is the content likely to impact public safety or cause serious harm?

On a case by case basis, Twitter states that it may also reduce the tweet's visibility and/or alert users in liking or retweeting.

fields.summary: Twitter lifts its ban on political ads. The current policy is country specific. In the US it is quite permissive; however, there is no information on the review process by which content would be deemed "false or misleading."
fields.details:
Advertisers may not promote false or misleading content. This includes: 

  • False or misleading information about how to participate in an election.
  • False or misleading information intended to intimidate or dissuade people from participating in an election. 
  • False or misleading information intended to undermine public confidence in an election.

fields.summary: Introduction of authorization process confirming the identify and location of entities running ads.
New spend trackers for House and Senate races.
Twitter's former head of trust and safety describes Twitter's trust and safety program under Musk as "nonexistent."
Twitter bars advertising from Russia Today and Sputnik.
Following the 2016 elections, Twitter articulates a focus for its election integrity work on "combat[ting] bots and networks of manipulation on Twitter" -- from automated accounts.
fields.details: This focus appears to be driven by concerns about Russian bots on Twitter during the 2016 election.

fields.summary: As a part of their plan for the 2024 election, Meta announces that "advertisers will also have to disclose when they use AI or other digital techniques to create or alter a political or social issue ad in certain cases."
fields.details: Meta states that the following requirements concerning political ads will remain unchanged: advertisers will complete an authorization process, ads will include a “paid for by” disclaimer, and be included in the Ad Library.

fields.summary: Facebook limits circulation of unverified NY Post story concerning Hunter Biden pending fact checking.
It is announced that Threads will operate on the fediverse.
fields.details:
The fediverse is "a collection of decentralised social media platforms that operate using open standards and protocols ... [and] allows users to interact and communicate across multiple platforms seamlessly." This structure "reduces the reliance on centralized data silos, giving users the ability to host their data on their own servers or trusted instances." However, it also enable bad actors: "the metadata that big platforms use to tie accounts to a single actor or detect abusive behavior at scale aren't available"

"Alex Stamos, the director of the Stanford Internet Observatory and former head of security at Meta, posted on Threads that the company would face greater challenges in performing key types of content moderation enforcement without access to back-end data about users who post banned content."

fields.summary: In a series of revisions over 2019 and 2020, Facebook expands its policy as to what constitutes voter interference and would necessitate removal. They also add items related to census participation (census interference).
fields.details:
Election related additions:

  • Misrepresentation of whether a candidate is running or not
  • Content stating that voting participation may or will result in law enforcement consequences
  • Statements that advocate, provide instructions, or show explicit intent to illegally participate in a voting
  • Calls for coordinated interference that would affect an individual’s ability to participate in an election
  • Content claiming that the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) is at a voting location
  • Explicit claims that people will be infected by COVID (or another communicable disease) if they participate in the voting process.

fields.summary: Twitter launches 'Birdwatch,' a community-driven content moderation program.
fields.details:
"Birdwatch allows people to identify information in Tweets they believe is misleading and write notes that provide informative context."

Initially launched as a pilot program, Birdwatch (later Community Notes) is subsequently expanded. External experts generally describe Birdwatch as nonexistent. In order to be posted to the public, a note just be upvoted by other members. This effectively screens out any ideologically charged content.

fields.summary: Meta announces the merger of its Business Integrity Unit, the team that moderates ad content, with its Central Integrity Team, which moderates user posts.
fields.details: "Meta will be held to the same standards for content moderation across both types of content ... whether ads or organic posts from everyday users."

fields.summary: TikTok undertakes education efforts towards paid content creators concerning election content.
fields.details: "If we discover political content was paid for and not properly disclosed, it is promptly removed from the platform."

fields.summary: Facebook imposes increased requirements for proving identity in order to submit political ads.
fields.details: The change aims to confirm that the entity running the political ad is U.S. based - organizations must provide a Federal Election Commission ID, Tax-ID number, or a government website domain that matches an email ending in .gov or .mil. The change claims to "help people on Facebook and Instagram better understand who’s trying to influence them and why. Now, with one tap, people will not only see information about the ad, but they’ll be able to see the information Facebook confirmed, such as whether an advertiser used an EIN or FEC identification number. This will allow people to confidently gauge the legitimacy of an organization and quickly raise questions or concerns if they find anything out of the ordinary."

fields.summary: Ad Archive replaced by Ad Library.
fields.details:
"Facebook’s Ads Archive that launched in May 2018 previously only included ads related to politics or policy issues, but now shows all active ads about anything, as well as inactive political and issue ads. It displays Page creation dates, mergers with other Pages, Page name changes and where a Page is managed from, and the option to report an ad for policy violation."

"The improved transparency could allow researchers, government investigators, journalists or anyone play watchdog to ensure ads aren’t being misused to spread misinformation, suppress voting, exacerbate polarization or otherwise be sketchy."

fields.summary: Twitter suspends Trump's accounts due to inciting violence in the wake of January 6.
fields.details: "We have permanently suspended the account due to the risk of further incitement of violence ... After assessing the language in these Tweets against our Glorification of Violence policy, we have determined that these Tweets are in violation of the Glorification of Violence Policy and the user @realDonaldTrump should be immediately permanently suspended from the service."

fields.summary: Facebook rolls out third party fact checking program.
fields.details:
"We’ll use the reports from our community, along with other signals, to send stories to [third party fact checkers.] If the fact checking organizations identify a story as fake, it will get flagged as disputed and there will be a link to the corresponding article explaining why. Stories that have been disputed may also appear lower in News Feed."

From its introduction, politicians have been exempt from fact checking under the logic that "accountability only works if we can see what those in power seeking our votes are saying and it’s scrutinized and debated in public. Even if we viscerally disagree with what they say." This applies to "a claim is made directly by a politician on their Page, in an ad or on their website."

fields.summary: The Washington Post reports that "Meta has quietly begun offering users new controls to opt out of the fact-checking program, allowing debunked posts ... to spread in participants’ news-feeds with a warning label."
TikTok begins labeling political figure accounts and content relevant to elections.
fields.details: "Labels to content identified as being related to the 2022 midterm elections as well as content from accounts belonging to governments, politicians, and political parties in the US."

fields.summary: Framed under the Civic Integrity Policy, Twitter adds feature that encourages users to think twice around retweeting misleading information.
fields.details: When retweeting "misleading information label, [users] will see a prompt pointing them to credible information about the topic before they are able to amplify it."

fields.summary: Twitter announces #BeAVoter campaign to drive voter registration.
Added label to posts that claim premature electoral victory.
fields.details: The warning text reads: "Votes are being counted. The winner of the 2020 US Presidential Election has not been projected. See Election updates."

fields.summary: YouTube updates its Ads Misrepresentation policy.
fields.details: "prohibit coordinating with other sites or accounts and concealing or misrepresenting your identity or other material details about yourself, where your content relates to politics, social issues, or matters of public concern"

fields.summary: Mark Zuckerberg defends decision to allow political ads on Facebook saying a ban “would favor incumbents and favor the people the media covers the most.”
Expansion of fact checking partnerships to cover election content.
fields.details: "We're expanding our partnerships with PolitiFact and Lead Stories to fact check potential misinformation related to the 2020 US election."

fields.summary: YouTube adds 'voting by mail' to the list of sensitive topics that triggers an information panel.
Twitter launches 2020 Election Hub at top of Explore tab.
fields.details: The Hub includes: English and Spanish language election news "in the form of Twitter Moments created by reputable news outlets themselves"; debate and other election event livestreams; voter educations PSAs.

fields.summary: Reorg of relevant community standards. Voter/Census Interference rolled into 'Misrepresentation' Category, Voter/Census Fraud still present under 'Coordinating Harm.'
fields.details:
Two categories of posts previously under take down recategorised as 'Additional info/context needed to enforce':

  • Calls for coordinated interference that would affect an individual’s ability to participate in the census or an election
  • Content stating that census or voting participation may or will result in law enforcement consequences (e.g., arrest, deportation, imprisonment)

One new category, housed under 'Additional info/context needed to enforce', prohibits content that includes "statements of intent, support or advocacy to go to an election site, voting location, or vote counting location when the purpose of going to the site is to monitor or watch voters or election officials’ activity using militaristic language (e.g. “war,” “army,” or “soldier” ) or an expressed goal to intimidate, exert control or display power (e.g. “Let’s show them who's boss!,” “If they’re scared, they won’t vote!”)."

fields.summary: Twitter loosens policy to allow for Trump's tweet telling minority members of Congress to "go back to where you came from."
Launch of Elections Center (as used for 2020 election).
fields.details: "Connect[s] people who engage with election content to authoritative information and sources in more than 45 languages ... our in-app center will feature videos that encourage our community to think critically about content they see online, as well as information about voting in the election. For any action that requires a user to share information, such as registering to vote, users will be directed away from TikTok onto the website for the state or relevant non-profit in order to carry out that process."

fields.summary: A modified version of Parler returns to the Apple App Store, and subsequently to the Google Play Store. Posts identified through the platform's 'trolling filter' are not visible on the app version (although they remain visible on the web/other versions).
TikTok announces "a new tool to help creators label their AI-generated content. We'll also start testing ways to label AI-generated content automatically."
fields.details: Twitter's annoucement does not address the technical challenges of identifying AI content.

fields.summary: Enhanced account security for  government officials, candidates for office, journalists for 2022 elections announced.
Election Explore Tab for 2022 elections launched (previously Election Hub).
fields.details: "Centralized hub for real-time political conversation, resources, and breaking news," includes PSAs about voting.

fields.summary: First 4 of 16 papers released assessing "the impact of Facebook and Instagram on key political attitudes and behaviors during the US 2020 election cycle."
fields.details: Meta touts their unprecedented collaboration and transparency with researchers and states that "the experimental findings add to a growing body of research showing there is little evidence that key features of Meta’s platforms alone cause harmful ‘affective’ polarization or have meaningful effects on these outcomes." While media coverage of the papers generally mirrors Meta's messaging, researchers point to overlooked nuance. In particular, the short timeframe for the data collection (3 months) and its timing (near the 2020 elections, when opinions were likely already formed) limit broader relevance of the findings.

fields.summary: Meta bars political advertisements from using the Meta Generative AI ads creation tools in Ads Manager.
fields.details: "Advertisers running campaigns that qualify as ads for Housing, Employment or Credit or Social Issues, Elections, or Politics, or related to Health, Pharmaceuticals or Financial Services aren't currently permitted to use these Generative AI features."

fields.summary: YouTube adds label to videos that come from state-funded media outlets.
fields.details: 1.5 years after the rollout of the labeling policy, a ProPublic report found mixed enforcement: "the world’s most popular streaming service allowed 57 channels funded by the governments of Iran, Russia, China, Turkey and Qatar, among others, to play videos without labels."

fields.summary: President Trump is banned from Facebook and Instagram.
fields.details: The initial ban in indefinite, later amended to a 2 year ban following a recommendation from the Oversight Board.

fields.summary: Changes to algorithm to preference authoritative sources in search results.
Candidate verification and account labeling rolled out, with the aim of avoiding counterfeit accounts.

X rationalizes its new allowance for political advertising citing freedom of expression and promises forthcoming updates to the Civil Integrity Policy that align with their new philosophy of "freedom of speech, not reach."
fields.details:
X will also create a global advertising transparency center that allows people to review political posts being shown on X. The US specific policies concerning political advertising state that:

  • Advertisers may not promote false or misleading content about how to participate in an election,  dissuade people from participating in an election or intended to undermine public confidence in an election.
  • Only U.S. persons and entities can run political ads in the U.S. and must go through a pre-approval process in order to do so.

X further plays up Community Notes (formerly Birdwatch) noting that it "empower[s] our users to express their opinions and openly debate during elections, in line with our commitment to protecting freedom of expression."

fields.summary: In lead up to 2022 election, The Washington Post conducts an analysis of candidate posts claiming rigged/fraudulent elections and finds that virtually none are labeled on Facebook or Twitter.
Meta dissolves its Responsible Innovation Team.
fields.details: The Responsible Innovation Team consisted of "roughly two dozen engineers, ethicists and others who collaborated with internal product teams and outside privacy specialists, academics and users to identify and address potential concerns [and downsides] about new products and alterations to Facebook and Instagram."
